segment.source: Use speech recognition to provide input, specify an action or command, and accomplish tasks.
segment.target: Use speech recognition to provide input, specify an action or command, and accomplish tasks.

segment.source: Speech recognition
segment.target: Speech recognition

segment.source: Speech recognition
segment.target: Speech recognition

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Use speech recognition to provide input, specify an action or command, and accomplish tasks.
segment.target: Use speech recognition to provide input, specify an action or command, and accomplish tasks.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.Media.SpeechRecognition
segment.target: Windows.Media.SpeechRecognition

segment.source: Speech recognition is made up of a speech runtime, recognition APIs for programming the runtime, ready-to-use grammars for dictation and web search, and a default system UI that helps users discover and use speech recognition features.
segment.target: Speech recognition is made up of a speech runtime, recognition APIs for programming the runtime, ready-to-use grammars for dictation and web search, and a default system UI that helps users discover and use speech recognition features.

segment.source: Set up the audio feed
segment.target: Set up the audio feed

segment.source: Ensure that your device has a microphone or the equivalent.
segment.target: Ensure that your device has a microphone or the equivalent.

segment.source: Set the Microphone device capability (DeviceCapability) in the App package manifest (package.appxmanifest file) to get access to the microphone’s audio feed.
segment.target: Set the Microphone device capability (DeviceCapability) in the App package manifest (package.appxmanifest file) to get access to the microphone’s audio feed.

segment.source: This allows the app to record audio from connected microphones.
segment.target: This allows the app to record audio from connected microphones.

segment.source: See App capability declarations.
segment.target: See App capability declarations.

segment.source: Recognize speech input
segment.target: Recognize speech input

segment.source: A constraint defines the words and phrases (vocabulary) that an app recognizes in speech input.
segment.target: A constraint defines the words and phrases (vocabulary) that an app recognizes in speech input.

segment.source: Constraints are at the core of speech recognition and give your app great over the accuracy of speech recognition.
segment.target: Constraints are at the core of speech recognition and give your app great over the accuracy of speech recognition.

segment.source: You can use various types of constraints when performing speech recognition:
segment.target: You can use various types of constraints when performing speech recognition:

segment.source: Predefined grammars (SpeechRecognitionTopicConstraint).
segment.target: Predefined grammars (SpeechRecognitionTopicConstraint).

segment.source: Predefined dictation and web-search grammars provide speech recognition for your app without requiring you to author a grammar.
segment.target: Predefined dictation and web-search grammars provide speech recognition for your app without requiring you to author a grammar.

segment.source: When using these grammars, speech recognition is performed by a remote web service and the results are returned to the device.
segment.target: When using these grammars, speech recognition is performed by a remote web service and the results are returned to the device.

segment.source: The default free-text dictation grammar can recognize most words and phrases that a user can say in a particular language, and is optimized to recognize short phrases.
segment.target: The default free-text dictation grammar can recognize most words and phrases that a user can say in a particular language, and is optimized to recognize short phrases.

segment.source: The predefined dictation grammar is used if you don't specify any constraints for your SpeechRecognizer object.
segment.target: The predefined dictation grammar is used if you don't specify any constraints for your SpeechRecognizer object.

segment.source: Free-text dictation is useful when you don't want to limit the kinds of things a user can say.
segment.target: Free-text dictation is useful when you don't want to limit the kinds of things a user can say.

segment.source: Typical uses include creating notes or dictating the content for a message.
segment.target: Typical uses include creating notes or dictating the content for a message.

segment.source: The web-search grammar, like a dictation grammar, contains a large number of words and phrases that a user might say.
segment.target: The web-search grammar, like a dictation grammar, contains a large number of words and phrases that a user might say.

segment.source: However, it is optimized to recognize terms that people typically use when searching the web.
segment.target: However, it is optimized to recognize terms that people typically use when searching the web.

segment.source: Note Because predefined dictation and web-search grammars can be large, and because they are online (not on the device), performance might not be as fast as with a custom grammar installed on the device.
segment.target: Note Because predefined dictation and web-search grammars can be large, and because they are online (not on the device), performance might not be as fast as with a custom grammar installed on the device.

segment.source: These predefined grammars can be used to recognize up to 10 seconds of speech input and require no authoring effort on your part.
segment.target: These predefined grammars can be used to recognize up to 10 seconds of speech input and require no authoring effort on your part.

segment.source: However, they do require a connection to a network.
segment.target: However, they do require a connection to a network.

segment.source: To use web-service constraints, speech input and dictation support must be enabled in Settings by turning on the "Get to know me" option in the Settings - Privacy - Speech, inking, and typing page.
segment.target: To use web-service constraints, speech input and dictation support must be enabled in Settings by turning on the "Get to know me" option in the Settings - Privacy - Speech, inking, and typing page.

segment.source: Here, we show how to test whether speech input is enabled and open the Settings - Privacy - Speech, inking, and typing page, if not.
segment.target: Here, we show how to test whether speech input is enabled and open the Settings - Privacy - Speech, inking, and typing page, if not.

segment.source: First, we initialize a global variable (HResultPrivacyStatementDeclined) to the HResult value of 0x80045509.
segment.target: First, we initialize a global variable (HResultPrivacyStatementDeclined) to the HResult value of 0x80045509.

segment.source: See Exception handling for in C# or Visual Basic.
segment.target: See Exception handling for in C# or Visual Basic.

segment.source: Programmatic list constraints (SpeechRecognitionListConstraint).
segment.target: Programmatic list constraints (SpeechRecognitionListConstraint).

segment.source: Programmatic list constraints provide a lightweight approach to creating simple grammars using a list of words or phrases.
segment.target: Programmatic list constraints provide a lightweight approach to creating simple grammars using a list of words or phrases.

segment.source: A list constraint works well for recognizing short, distinct phrases.
segment.target: A list constraint works well for recognizing short, distinct phrases.

segment.source: Explicitly specifying all words in a grammar also improves recognition accuracy, as the speech recognition engine must only process speech to confirm a match.
segment.target: Explicitly specifying all words in a grammar also improves recognition accuracy, as the speech recognition engine must only process speech to confirm a match.

segment.source: The list can also be programmatically updated.
segment.target: The list can also be programmatically updated.

segment.source: A list constraint consists of an array of strings that represents speech input that your app will accept for a recognition operation.
segment.target: A list constraint consists of an array of strings that represents speech input that your app will accept for a recognition operation.

segment.source: You can create a list constraint in your app by creating a speech-recognition list-constraint object and passing an array of strings.
segment.target: You can create a list constraint in your app by creating a speech-recognition list-constraint object and passing an array of strings.

segment.source: Then, add that object to the constraints collection of the recognizer.
segment.target: Then, add that object to the constraints collection of the recognizer.

segment.source: Recognition is successful when the speech recognizer recognizes any one of the strings in the array.
segment.target: Recognition is successful when the speech recognizer recognizes any one of the strings in the array.

segment.source: SRGS grammars (SpeechRecognitionGrammarFileConstraint).
segment.target: SRGS grammars (SpeechRecognitionGrammarFileConstraint).

segment.source: An Speech Recognition Grammar Specification (SRGS) grammar is a static document that, unlike a programmatic list constraint, uses the XML format defined by the SRGS Version 1.0.
segment.target: An Speech Recognition Grammar Specification (SRGS) grammar is a static document that, unlike a programmatic list constraint, uses the XML format defined by the SRGS Version 1.0.

segment.source: An SRGS grammar provides the greatest control over the speech recognition experience by letting you capture multiple semantic meanings in a single recognition.
segment.target: An SRGS grammar provides the greatest control over the speech recognition experience by letting you capture multiple semantic meanings in a single recognition.

segment.source: Voice command constraints (SpeechRecognitionVoiceCommandDefinitionConstraint)
segment.target: Voice command constraints (SpeechRecognitionVoiceCommandDefinitionConstraint)

segment.source: Use a Voice Command Definition (VCD) XML file to define the commands that the user can say to initiate actions when activating your app.
segment.target: Use a Voice Command Definition (VCD) XML file to define the commands that the user can say to initiate actions when activating your app.

segment.source: For more detail, see Launch a foreground app with voice commands in Cortana.
segment.target: For more detail, see Launch a foreground app with voice commands in Cortana.

segment.source: Note Which type of constraint type you use depends on the complexity of the recognition experience you want to create.
segment.target: Note Which type of constraint type you use depends on the complexity of the recognition experience you want to create.

segment.source: Any could be the best choice for a specific recognition task, and you might find uses for all types of constraints in your app.
segment.target: Any could be the best choice for a specific recognition task, and you might find uses for all types of constraints in your app.

segment.source: To get started with constraints, see Define custom recognition constraints.
segment.target: To get started with constraints, see Define custom recognition constraints.

segment.source: The predefined Universal Windows app dictation grammar recognizes most words and short phrases in a language.
segment.target: The predefined Universal Windows app dictation grammar recognizes most words and short phrases in a language.

segment.source: It is activated by default when a speech recognizer object is instantiated without custom constraints.
segment.target: It is activated by default when a speech recognizer object is instantiated without custom constraints.

segment.source: In this example, we show how to:
segment.target: In this example, we show how to:

segment.source: Create a speech recognizer.
segment.target: Create a speech recognizer.

segment.source: Compile the default Universal Windows app constraints (no grammars have been added to the speech recognizer's grammar set).
segment.target: Compile the default Universal Windows app constraints (no grammars have been added to the speech recognizer's grammar set).

segment.source: Start listening for speech by using the basic recognition UI and TTS feedback provided by the RecognizeWithUIAsync method.
segment.target: Start listening for speech by using the basic recognition UI and TTS feedback provided by the RecognizeWithUIAsync method.

segment.source: Use the RecognizeAsync method if the default UI is not required.
segment.target: Use the RecognizeAsync method if the default UI is not required.

segment.source: Customize the recognition UI
segment.target: Customize the recognition UI

segment.source: When your app attempts speech recognition by calling SpeechRecognizer.RecognizeWithUIAsync, several screens are shown in the following order.
segment.target: When your app attempts speech recognition by calling SpeechRecognizer.RecognizeWithUIAsync, several screens are shown in the following order.

segment.source: If you're using a constraint based on a predefined grammar (dictation or web search):
segment.target: If you're using a constraint based on a predefined grammar (dictation or web search):

segment.source: The Listening screen.
segment.target: The Listening screen.

segment.source: The Thinking screen.
segment.target: The Thinking screen.

segment.source: The Heard you say screen or the error screen.
segment.target: The Heard you say screen or the error screen.

segment.source: If you're using a constraint based on a list of words or phrases, or a constraint based on a SRGS grammar file:
segment.target: If you're using a constraint based on a list of words or phrases, or a constraint based on a SRGS grammar file:

segment.source: The Listening screen.
segment.target: The Listening screen.

segment.source: The Did you say screen, if what the user said could be interpreted as more than one potential result.
segment.target: The Did you say screen, if what the user said could be interpreted as more than one potential result.

segment.source: The Heard you say screen or the error screen.
segment.target: The Heard you say screen or the error screen.

segment.source: The following image shows an example of the flow between screens for a speech recognizer that uses a constraint based on a SRGS grammar file.
segment.target: The following image shows an example of the flow between screens for a speech recognizer that uses a constraint based on a SRGS grammar file.

segment.source: In this example, speech recognition was successful.
segment.target: In this example, speech recognition was successful.

segment.source: initial recognition screen for a constraint based on a sgrs grammar file
segment.target: initial recognition screen for a constraint based on a sgrs grammar file

segment.source: intermediate recognition screen for a constraint based on a sgrs grammar file
segment.target: intermediate recognition screen for a constraint based on a sgrs grammar file

segment.source: final recognition screen for a constraint based on a sgrs grammar file
segment.target: final recognition screen for a constraint based on a sgrs grammar file

segment.source: The Listening screen can provide examples of words or phrases that the app can recognize.
segment.target: The Listening screen can provide examples of words or phrases that the app can recognize.

segment.source: Here, we show how to use the properties of the SpeechRecognizerUIOptions class (obtained by calling the SpeechRecognizer.UIOptions property) to customize content on the Listening screen.
segment.target: Here, we show how to use the properties of the SpeechRecognizerUIOptions class (obtained by calling the SpeechRecognizer.UIOptions property) to customize content on the Listening screen.
